THAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Harry Nelson
Address Bergeley Road
Birthplace Macalister, Eng.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? Pragnell, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Pragnell District
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3 to 5
How far was it to your nearest store? 15 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
flour, oatmeal, sugar, jam, tea,

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Argyle
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.65
How much did you use graham flour? very little
Whole wheat flour? very little
Was flour milled locally? yes How far away? 20 What year? 1908-12
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? .............
What other grain products did you use? ........................................
Cornmeal? very little Whole wheat? no Farina? small amount 50 lbs
Other? Breadstuffs
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? yes
How did you grind it? Ground at the mill

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Butcher shop.

How did you get fresh meat? Bought from butcher shop.

How often did you get fresh meat? About once a week.

How did you preserve meat? Salt method.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasant, chicken, antelope.

For how long? During fall & winter.

What part did fish play in the family diet? None.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned.

Kinds? Salmon.
